Pre-Game Insights: A sudden, intense rain shower lasting about five minutes disrupted New Zealand's training session.
The ground staff quickly took action to address the situation.
The weather forecast for Saturday, November 4, looks grim as New Zealand faces Pakistan in what could be a virtual knockout match to secure a spot in the 2023 World Cup.

New Zealand had a strong start with four consecutive victories, even holding the top spot in the standings, but three consecutive losses to India, Australia, and South Africa have put them on the fringes of the qualification bracket.
Pakistan is in an even more precarious position, needing both points and favorable outcomes.
Pakistan's campaign has been marred by a series of injuries to key players, starting with Kane Williamson's broken thumb shortly after his return from an ACL injury.
Their bowling department is particularly affected, with Matt Henry being the latest casualty due to a grade two hamstring tear, leading to his replacement by Kyle Jamieson.
In this do-or-die situation, Pakistan remained composed during their three-hour practice session.
Coach Mickey Arthur praised the players' calm demeanor, contrasting it with his own nervousness.
Pakistan's inconsistent batting department is a concern, despite their bowling unit showing signs of improvement.
Fakhar Zaman returned to the opening spot and justified his inclusion with a brisk 81 in the victory against Bangladesh.
However, the middle-order batters, Iftikhar Ahmed and Saud Shakeel, have not performed exceptionally, and captain Babar Azam's three fifties have only masked the team's batting issues.
To secure victory, especially on a challenging Chinnaswamy pitch for bowlers, Pakistan will need a near-perfect all-round performance, even against a battered New Zealand side.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Chinnaswamy Stadium has a 'Sub Air System' installed which not only prevents the outfield from water logging but also drains water 36 times faster than the natural drainage time.
The Sub Air system automatically kicks into action the minute it starts raining, thereby not allowing any buildup of water on the outfield.
Others: Mark Chapman, Lockie Ferguson, Jimmy Neesham, and Kane Williamson all trained in Bengaluru on Friday.
A decision on their availability to feature against Pakistan will be left until game-day and likely confirmed at the toss.
New Zealand needs to secure two wins in their remaining matches to simplify their path to the knockout stage.
Pakistan is currently in fifth place with four consecutive defeats but a morale-boosting victory against Bangladesh revived their hopes.
Pakistan's best chance is to win big against New Zealand (or at least win in general) so a rained-out match would be a big blow.
